disposable_income: Rogers Park has a median household income of around $47,000, lower than Chicago's median. About 27% of residents live below poverty level. Many residents are cost-sensitive and need to carefully manage transportation expenses.
discretionary_consumption: Given the income levels, residents have limited discretionary spending. Many are students or working-class families who need to balance basic needs with transportation costs. Higher sales taxes would notably impact household budgets.
accessibility: High transit dependency with good access to CTA Red Line and multiple bus routes. About 35% of households don't own cars. Many residents commute to work/school using public transit. Walking and biking are common for local trips.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize low transit fares due to high transit dependency and lower incomes. 2. Moderate sales tax to maintain transit service without overly burdening limited discretionary spending. 3. Support some driving fees to improve transit service and reduce congestion, but not highest level given some residents need cars. 4. Balance between transit time improvements and cost burden. 5. Selected proposals that reduce transit travel times while keeping fares affordable.

disposable_income: West Ridge has a median household income of around $54,000, which is moderate for Chicago. About 19% of residents live below poverty level, indicating a significant portion of population is price-sensitive to transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: The community has moderate discretionary spending power. Many residents are working-class and middle-class families who need to carefully balance transportation costs with other essential expenses. The area has a significant immigrant population who tend to be price-conscious consumers
accessibility: The area has moderate transit access with several bus routes and proximity to the Red Line. About 30% of residents use public transit for commuting, while 60% drive. The community is relatively far from downtown, making travel times a crucial factor. Many residents need cars to access jobs and services
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize balanced policies that don't overly burden either drivers or transit users given the mixed-mode usage. 2. Consider moderate tax rates to improve service while maintaining affordability. 3. Favor policies that reduce transit travel times since many residents commute long distances. 4. Look for proposals that offer good time savings without excessive costs. 5. Selected proposals 11, 13, 10, 19, and 4 as they offer good balance of improved transit times, moderate costs, and reasonable driving conditions

disposable_income: Uptown has mixed income levels with median household income around $53,000. About 20% of residents live below poverty line. Many residents are cost-sensitive when it comes to transportation expenses.
discretionary_consumption: Significant portion of residents have limited discretionary spending. Higher sales taxes would impact local businesses and resident purchasing power. Many residents rely on public transit for essential trips.
accessibility: Well-served by CTA Red Line, multiple bus routes, and Lake Shore Drive. High transit dependency with ~40% of households not owning cars. Dense, walkable neighborhood with many local amenities. Good mix of transit and driving options.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower transit fares due to high transit dependency and lower incomes. 2. Moderate sales tax to balance revenue needs with impact on discretionary spending. 3. Support driving fees to improve transit service without overly burdening drivers. 4. Focus on proposals that reduce transit travel times to benefit transit-dependent population. 5. Consider balance of car vs transit improvements given mixed-mode usage.

disposable_income: Lincoln Square is a middle to upper-middle income area with median household income around $77,000. Residents have moderate disposable income but are price-sensitive to transportation costs.
discretionary_consumption: The area has significant retail and entertainment spending, with many local businesses, restaurants, and shopping districts. Residents generally have good discretionary spending power but are value-conscious.
accessibility: Well-served by CTA Brown Line, multiple bus routes, and major arterial roads. High transit usage (40%+ commuters), significant walking/biking, but also considerable car ownership. Good mix of transportation options.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize balanced policies that maintain good transit service while keeping costs moderate for both transit and driving users. 2. Favor proposals with moderate sales tax (1%) as community has retail spending but wants to maintain local business vitality. 3. Support modest driver fees to reduce congestion but avoid highest fees that could hurt local businesses. 4. Look for proposals that improve transit times without excessive fare increases. 5. Selected proposals 13, 10, 4, 14, and 16 as they offer good transit time improvements with moderate cost impacts across all modes.

disposable_income: North Center is an affluent area with median household income around $110,000, significantly above Chicago's average. Residents have relatively high disposable income and can generally afford higher transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: Area has high discretionary spending power, with many residents spending on dining, entertainment, and retail. Higher sales tax would have moderate impact but not severely constrain spending habits
accessibility: Well-served by Brown Line, multiple bus routes, and major arterial roads. 71% of residents commute by car, 21% by transit. Area has good transportation options and infrastructure for both modes
decision_rationale: 1. Given high income levels, prioritize time savings over cost savings. 2. Support policies that improve both transit and driving times since area uses both modes significantly. 3. Can absorb higher taxes/fees for better service. 4. Higher driver fees acceptable to reduce congestion. 5. Moderate transit fares to maintain ridership. Selected policies balance service improvements with reasonable cost increases, focusing on proposals with 1.0-1.5% tax rates that generate revenue for system improvements while maintaining affordability

disposable_income: Lake View is an affluent area with median household income around $90,000. Residents have relatively high disposable income and can generally afford higher transportation costs. Many residents work in professional services and have stable incomes.
discretionary_consumption: The area has high discretionary spending power, with numerous restaurants, entertainment venues, and retail shops. Residents frequently engage in recreational activities and dining out. Higher sales taxes would have a moderate but not severe impact on consumption patterns.
accessibility: Lake View has excellent transit access with multiple L lines (Red, Brown, Purple) and numerous bus routes. High walkability score and bike-friendly infrastructure. Many residents commute to downtown. Car ownership is lower than city average due to good transit options and parking challenges.
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize policies that improve transit service given high transit usage in area
2. Higher income means community can tolerate moderate fare/fee increases if service improves
3. Support driving fees to reduce congestion on busy arterials
4. Balance tax burden against service improvements
5. Focus on options that reduce transit travel times most significantly
6. Selected proposals 26, 23, 14, 20, and 11 as they offer best transit time improvements while maintaining reasonable fare levels

disposable_income: Lincoln Park is one of Chicago's most affluent neighborhoods with median household income over $115,000. Residents have high disposable income and can generally afford higher transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: High levels of discretionary spending on retail, dining, and entertainment. The community has significant retail corridors and residents tend to make frequent trips for shopping and leisure activities
accessibility: Well-served by public transit with multiple L stations (Red/Brown/Purple lines) and bus routes. High car ownership rates but also high transit usage. Dense, walkable neighborhood with many destinations accessible by multiple modes
decision_rationale: 1. Given high incomes, can tolerate higher fees/taxes to fund better service. 2. Many residents use both cars and transit, so balanced improvements to both modes are valuable. 3. Higher driver fees acceptable as they reduce congestion in dense area. 4. Prefer options that significantly improve transit times without extreme fare increases. 5. Selected proposals that balance service improvements with moderate cost increases across modes. Ranked based on overall time savings and reasonable cost structure

disposable_income: Near North Side has one of the highest median household incomes in Chicago (over $100,000). Residents have significant disposable income and can generally afford higher transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: High levels of discretionary spending, with numerous luxury retail, dining, and entertainment venues. Residents typically spend more on goods/services, meaning sales tax impact is higher in absolute terms
accessibility: Excellent transit access with multiple L lines, bus routes, and walkable streets. High car ownership but also high transit usage due to density and connectivity. Major employment/entertainment destination with significant traffic congestion
decision_rationale: 1. Given high incomes, can tolerate higher fees/taxes to improve service. 2. Heavy congestion means driving fees could significantly improve travel times. 3. Strong transit infrastructure means improvements will be widely utilized. 4. Dense mixed-use area benefits from reduced car traffic. 5. Higher transit fares acceptable given income levels if they improve service. Selected policies that balance congestion reduction through driving fees with transit improvements funded by moderate-to-high taxes and fares

disposable_income: Edison Park is an affluent community with median household income around $94,000, well above Chicago average. Residents have relatively high disposable income and can generally afford higher transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: High levels of discretionary spending power. Most households own cars and have significant retail spending. Higher sales taxes would have moderate but manageable impact on consumption
accessibility: Located on far northwest side, relatively car-dependent area with longer commute times to downtown. Has Metra station but limited CTA bus service. Most residents (80%+) commute by car. Good road access via I-90 and major arterials
decision_rationale:
1. Given high car dependency and income levels, policies with moderate driving fees are acceptable if they reduce congestion
2. Higher sales tax is tolerable given affluence, if it improves transit
3. Moderate transit fares preferred since most residents drive anyway
4. Prioritize proposals that reduce car travel times given heavy car usage
5. Balance between driving costs and congestion reduction is key for this car-centric community

disposable_income: Norwood Park is an upper-middle-class area with median household income around $82,000. Residents have relatively high disposable income and car ownership rates. Many households can afford multiple vehicles.
discretionary_consumption: Residents have significant discretionary spending capacity. The area has high rates of homeownership and retail spending. A sales tax increase would have moderate but manageable impact on household budgets.
accessibility: The area is served by the Blue Line and Metra, but many residents rely heavily on cars. The community is more car-dependent than inner city areas, with longer average commute times. Good road access but moderate transit coverage.
decision_rationale:
1. As a car-dependent community with higher incomes, policies with lower sales tax are preferred to preserve discretionary spending
2. Moderate driving fees are acceptable as residents can afford them and they improve transit
3. Higher transit fares are acceptable since most residents drive and higher fares fund better service
4. Focus on policies that reduce car travel times while maintaining reasonable transit options
5. Balance between maintaining car convenience and supporting transit improvements

disposable_income: Jefferson Park is a middle-class community with median household income around $71,000. Many residents are working professionals and city workers. The area has relatively high homeownership rates and stable housing costs.
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate discretionary spending power but are price-sensitive to additional taxes and fees. Many households have significant expenses related to housing, transportation, and family needs.
accessibility: The area is well-served by public transit with the Jefferson Park Transit Center (Blue Line, Metra, buses). However, many residents still rely on cars for work commutes and daily errands. The community has good road access via I-90 and major arterials.
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize balanced options that don't overly burden middle-class residents with high taxes/fees
2. Consider strong transit presence but acknowledge car dependency for many trips
3. Look for proposals that improve both transit and driving times without excessive costs
4. Favor moderate fare increases over high sales tax due to impact on overall household budgets
5. Select options that maintain reasonable transit access for transit-dependent residents

disposable_income: Forest Glen is an affluent area with median household income around $106,000, significantly higher than Chicago's average. Residents have relatively high disposable income and can generally afford higher transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: Residents have substantial discretionary spending power. The community has high rates of car ownership and many residents commute by car. The higher sales tax impact would be noticeable but manageable given income levels
accessibility: The area is car-dependent with limited transit access. Most residents rely on personal vehicles. The Metra Forest Glen station and some bus routes serve the area but with limited frequency. The Blue Line is not within walking distance for most residents
decision_rationale: 1. Given high car dependency, policies that improve driving times without excessive fees are preferred. 2. Higher sales tax is acceptable if it improves overall transportation. 3. Transit improvements are still valuable for workers and reducing congestion. 4. Focus on balanced options that don't overly burden drivers while still funding transit. 5. Selected policies that maintain reasonable driving costs while improving both car and transit times

disposable_income: North Park has a median household income of around $65,000, placing it in the middle-upper range for Chicago. Many residents are working professionals and families with moderate disposable income.
discretionary_consumption: The community has moderate to high discretionary spending capacity. Many residents own homes and cars, with significant regular expenditures on transportation, retail, and services. The 1-1.5% sales tax impact would be noticeable but manageable for most households.
accessibility: North Park has moderate transit access with bus routes and proximity to the Brown Line, though many residents rely on cars. The area has good road connectivity but experiences some congestion during peak hours. Many residents commute to downtown and other areas for work.
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize balanced policies that improve both transit and driving conditions without excessive costs
2. Consider moderate tax rates that can fund improvements while not overly burdening residents
3. Support policies that reduce congestion through reasonable driving fees
4. Look for options that maintain affordable transit fares while improving service
5. Choose proposals that offer the best time savings relative to cost increases

disposable_income: Albany Park has a median household income of around $53,000, lower than Chicago's average. About 16% of residents live below poverty level, indicating many residents have limited disposable income
discretionary_consumption: Given the moderate-to-low income levels, residents are price-sensitive to both transit fares and sales taxes. Many households need to carefully budget discretionary spending
accessibility: Well-served by CTA Brown Line, multiple bus routes, and major arterial roads. About 36% of residents use public transit for commuting, 45% drive, indicating balanced modal split. Many residents rely on both transit and driving
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower transit fares and moderate taxes given income constraints. 2. Balance driving fees to improve transit service without overly burdening drivers. 3. Consider high transit usage rate in community. 4. Focus on proposals that reduce transit travel time while keeping costs manageable. 5. Selected proposals 10, 11, 19, 20, and 13 as they offer good balance of improved transit times, moderate costs, and reasonable driving conditions

disposable_income: Middle-income neighborhood with median household income around $65,000. Many working families with moderate disposable income. About 10% poverty rate indicates some economic constraints
discretionary_consumption: Moderate discretionary spending capacity. Residents are price-sensitive but can afford some additional transportation costs. Many households have significant retail spending in local commercial districts
accessibility: Mixed transit access - served by Blue Line and multiple bus routes but not as extensive as downtown areas. High car ownership rates (80%+ households). Many residents commute by both car and transit. Good road network with access to expressways
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize balanced options that don't overly burden either drivers or transit users given mixed transportation needs. 2. Moderate tax rates preferred due to middle-income status. 3. Look for proposals that improve transit service while keeping costs reasonable. 4. Consider proposals that reduce congestion given high car usage. 5. Selected proposals 10, 13, 4, 19, and 22 as they offer: a) Modest tax increases (0.5-1.5%), b) Reasonable transit fares ($0.75-1.25), c) Moderate driving fees ($0.50) to manage congestion, d) Good improvements in both transit and driving times

disposable_income: Irving Park has a median household income of approximately $71,000, which is above Chicago's median. About 10% of residents live below poverty level. The community has a mix of middle-class and working-class households with moderate disposable income.
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate discretionary spending capacity. The area has a significant number of homeowners with mortgage obligations. Higher sales taxes would impact household budgets but not severely given the income levels.
accessibility: The area has good transit access with Blue Line, Metra UP-NW, and multiple bus routes. Car ownership is high at about 80% of households. Mixed-use development along commercial corridors means many amenities are accessible by both transit and car.
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize balanced policies that maintain transit service while not overly burdening drivers given high car ownership
2. Moderate fare increases acceptable given income levels, but avoid highest fares
3. Support some driving fees to reduce congestion and fund transit
4. Prefer lower sales tax rates to preserve discretionary spending
5. Value policies that reduce transit travel times given good existing transit infrastructure

disposable_income: Dunning is a middle-class community with median household income around $69,000. Most residents are working professionals and families with moderate disposable income. The area has relatively high car ownership rates.
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate discretionary spending capacity. Many households own cars and spend significantly on transportation. A typical household makes regular shopping trips to nearby commercial areas and commutes to work.
accessibility: Dunning is a car-dependent community on Chicago's northwest side. Limited public transit access with some bus routes but no L train stations within the neighborhood. Most residents rely on personal vehicles for commuting and daily trips. The area has good road infrastructure but experiences some congestion during peak hours.
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize policies that maintain reasonable driving costs since most residents are car-dependent
2. Prefer lower sales tax rates to preserve discretionary spending power
3. Support moderate driving fees to reduce congestion while keeping transit fares affordable
4. Balance between travel time improvements and cost increases
5. Selected policies 4, 1, 13, 10, and 3 as they offer good compromises between driving costs, transit improvements, and tax burden

disposable_income: Montclare has a median household income of around $54,000, which is slightly below Chicago's median. Many residents are working-class families with moderate disposable income. About 12% of residents live below poverty level, making them sensitive to cost increases
discretionary_consumption: Given the moderate income levels, residents have limited discretionary spending. Most household budgets are allocated to essential needs. Higher taxes or transportation costs would significantly impact household budgets
accessibility: Montclare is a somewhat car-dependent neighborhood on Chicago's northwest side. While served by CTA buses, it lacks direct rail access. About 75% of residents drive to work, while 20% use public transit. The community has above-average car ownership rates
decision_rationale: 1. Given high car dependency but moderate incomes, prefer policies with lower driving fees and moderate taxes to avoid overburdening drivers. 2. Transit improvements should be balanced against cost impact on working families. 3. Policy 3 ranks first as it maintains low tax with no driving fee while keeping transit affordable. 4. Policy 9 second as it improves transit with moderate tax increase. 5. Policy 0 third as it reduces transit costs. 6. Policy 12 fourth as current policy. 7. Policy 4 fifth as balanced approach with minimal impact on drivers

disposable_income: Belmont Cragin is a working-class community with median household income around $47,000, below Chicago's average. Many residents work in service and manufacturing sectors, indicating limited disposable income
discretionary_consumption: Given the lower-than-average income levels, residents have limited discretionary spending. A significant portion of income goes to essential needs, making them sensitive to additional transportation costs and taxes
accessibility: The area has moderate transit access with bus services but no L train stations within the community. Car ownership is important for many residents due to work locations. About 30% of residents rely on public transit for commuting
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize lower transit fares ($0.75) to help transit-dependent residents
2. Prefer moderate tax rates (0.5-1.0%) to minimize impact on limited discretionary income
3. Support moderate driving fees ($0.50) to improve transit service without overly burdening drivers
4. Balance between transit improvement and cost burden on working families
5. Consider proposals that reduce transit travel time while keeping costs affordable

disposable_income: Hermosa is a working-class community with median household income around $47,000, below Chicago's average. Many residents work in service and manufacturing sectors, indicating limited disposable income

accessibility: The area has moderate transit access with bus routes and proximity to Blue Line, but many residents rely on cars for work commutes. About 75% of households own vehicles, but transit remains important for those without cars
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower transit fares and moderate taxes given limited disposable income. 2. Balance driving fees to improve transit without overly burdening car-dependent workers. 3. Consider proposals that reduce transit travel times to benefit both transit users and occasional drivers. 4. Avoid highest tax rates that would strain household budgets. 5. Select options that maintain reasonable car travel times while improving transit service

disposable_income: Avondale has a median household income of approximately $57,000, which is slightly below Chicago's median. About 15% of residents live below poverty level, suggesting moderate financial constraints for many households

accessibility: Avondale has good access to CTA Blue Line and multiple bus routes. About 32% of residents use public transit for commuting, while 55% drive. The area has a mix of transit-dependent and car-dependent households

Support modest driving fees ($0.50) to reduce congestion while not overly burdening drivers. 4. Focus on proposals that reduce transit travel times to benefit significant transit-using population. 5. Consider mixed-mode transportation needs of community

disposable_income: Logan Square has a median household income of around $71,000, slightly above Chicago's median. However, there's significant income diversity with about 15% of residents below poverty level. The area has seen gentrification leading to increased housing costs affecting disposable income.
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate discretionary spending power but face rising living costs. The area has many local businesses, restaurants, and entertainment venues that residents frequent. Higher sales taxes would impact this spending, especially for lower-income residents.
accessibility: Well-served by Blue Line L train and multiple bus routes. About 32% of residents use public transit for commuting, 45% drive, and others bike or walk. The area has good transit connectivity to downtown and neighboring areas. Many residents are multimodal, switching between transit and driving.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize balanced policies that maintain transit affordability while improving service. 2. Consider moderate driver fees to reduce congestion while not overly burdening drivers. 3. Prefer lower sales tax rates due to mixed-income population. 4. Focus on proposals that reduce transit travel times to benefit large transit-using population. 5. Selected proposals 11, 10, 13, 4, and 1 as they offer good balance of lower fares, moderate taxes, and improved transit times while maintaining affordability.

accessibility: About 35% of households don't own vehicles and rely heavily on public transit. The area has moderate transit access with several bus routes and proximity to Blue Line, but many residents face long commute times. Walking and biking are common modes of transportation

Consider policies that reduce transit travel times to improve accessibility to jobs and services

accessibility: Well-served by CTA Blue Line, multiple bus routes, bike lanes, and major arterial roads. Mixed-use development with good walkability. Many residents use multiple transportation modes regularly

Higher income means moderate fare/fee increases are acceptable if they improve service. 3. Lower sales tax preferred due to high discretionary spending. 4. Value proposals that reduce transit travel times since many residents use public transit. 5. Consider policies that manage congestion through moderate driving fees since many residents also drive

accessibility: Austin has access to Blue Line L and several bus routes, but many residents rely on public transit due to lower car ownership rates (about 65% of households have access to vehicles). The community experiences longer commute times than city average

Need balance between transit service quality and cost burden on residents. 3. Moderate driving fees acceptable as fewer residents drive. 4. Focus on proposals that improve transit times without excessive cost increases. 5. Selected proposals that reduce transit travel time while keeping fares affordable and taxes moderate

discretionary_consumption: Given the low income levels, residents have minimal discretionary spending capacity. Most income goes to essential needs like housing, food, and utilities. Higher taxes or transportation costs would significantly impact household budgets
accessibility: The area has moderate transit access via Green Line and bus routes but faces connectivity challenges. About 40% of households don't own vehicles and rely heavily on public transit. Average commute times are higher than city average

2. Need good transit service since many residents are transit-dependent 
3. Lower transit fares more important than driving fees since car ownership is low

Consider proposals that reduce both transit and driving times while keeping costs manageable for low-income residents

disposable_income: Near West Side has a mixed income profile with median household income around $71,000. The area includes both affluent professionals and lower-income residents. Major employers include the Illinois Medical District and University of Illinois Chicago.

2. Support moderate driving fees to reduce congestion while not overly burdening drivers

4. Balance travel time improvements with cost impacts across modes

disposable_income: North Lawndale has one of the lowest median household incomes in Chicago at around $25,000, with 43% of residents living below poverty level. This indicates very limited disposable income for transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: Given the high poverty rate and low income, discretionary spending is severely limited. Residents are highly sensitive to any additional costs from taxes, fares, or fees as they significantly impact their ability to afford basic necessities
accessibility: The area has moderate transit access with Pink Line stations and bus routes, but 30% of households don't own vehicles. Many residents rely on public transit for accessing jobs and services. Current transit travel times are long compared to driving

Need to maintain reasonable transit service given high transit dependency. 3. Moderate tax rate can help fund transit improvements. 4. Avoid high driving fees as many working residents need cars to access jobs. 5. Balance between travel time improvements and affordability. Selected proposals that minimize costs while maintaining adequate transit service levels

Lower fares are critical for transit-dependent residents. 4. Moderate driving fees acceptable since many don't drive. 5. Selected policies balance keeping transit affordable while generating enough revenue for service quality through driving fees and moderate tax

disposable_income: Lower West Side has a median household income of approximately $43,000, which is below Chicago's median. Many residents work in service and manufacturing jobs, with about 22% of the population living below poverty level. This suggests limited disposable income for many households.

Strong transit dependency means maintaining good transit service is crucial. 3. Lower driving fees preferred since many working families need cars for jobs/errands. 4. Balance between transit improvement and cost burden leads to moderate policy packages. 5. Selected proposals that maintain reasonable transit times while minimizing financial impact on residents.

disposable_income: The Loop has one of the highest median household incomes in Chicago, with many residents working in professional and financial services. The average household income is well above $100,000, indicating high disposable income and ability to absorb transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: Residents have significant discretionary spending power, with high levels of retail, dining, and entertainment expenditure. The impact of sales tax increases would be noticeable but manageable given the income levels
accessibility: The Loop has excellent transit accessibility with multiple L lines, Metra stations, and bus routes. It also has high walkability scores. While many residents own cars, transit is a viable and widely-used option for most trips. Traffic congestion is a major concern during peak hours

Higher driver fees acceptable as they discourage driving and reduce congestion. 4. Moderate to higher transit fares acceptable given income levels. 5. Higher tax rates justified if they significantly improve transit service. Selected policies that balance these factors while maximizing travel time improvements for both modes

accessibility: The area has excellent transit access with multiple L lines (Red, Green, Orange), bus routes, and Metra stations. Also has good road access to downtown and expressways. Mixed-use development means many amenities are within walking distance. High car ownership but also high transit usage for commuting.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize policies that balance transit improvements with moderate cost increases given high income levels. 2. discretionary_consumption: Limited discretionary spending capacity due to lower income levels. Higher sales taxes would significantly impact household budgets. Many families need to carefully balance transportation costs with other essential expenses.
accessibility: Mixed transit access with bus routes and proximity to Orange Line. About 27% of households don't own vehicles and rely on public transit. Car ownership costs are burdensome for many residents. Average commute times are significant factor for working population.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower transit fares ($0.75) due to high transit dependency and lower incomes. 2. Prefer lower sales tax (0.5-1.0%) to minimize impact on limited discretionary spending. 3. Support moderate driving fees ($0.50) to improve transit service without excessive burden. 4. Balance between transit improvement and cost burden leads to preference for proposals 1, 10, 11, 9, and 2. These provide good transit times while keeping costs manageable for residents.

disposable_income: West Englewood has one of the lowest median household incomes in Chicago at around $27,000. Many residents live below the poverty line, making disposable income extremely limited. The community has a high unemployment rate and many households rely on public assistance.
discretionary_consumption: Given the low income levels, discretionary spending is very limited. Most household income goes to basic necessities like housing, food, and utilities. Additional taxes or transportation costs would significantly impact already strained household budgets.
accessibility: The community has high transit dependency with lower car ownership rates. Many residents rely on public transit to access jobs, services and resources. The area is served by CTA buses and the Red Line, but transit travel times are long compared to driving. Improving transit affordability and service quality is crucial.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lowest transit fares ($0.75) given limited incomes and high transit dependency. 2. Favor lower sales tax rates (0.5-1.0%) to minimize impact on basic consumption. 3. Support moderate driving fees ($0.50-$1.00) to fund transit improvements while managing congestion. 4. Balance travel time improvements with cost burden on residents. 5. Focus on proposals that make transit more affordable and reliable for daily commuting needs.

disposable_income: Englewood has one of the lowest median household incomes in Chicago at around $20,000 annually. Many residents live below poverty level and have very limited disposable income. Cost sensitivity is extremely high.
discretionary_consumption: Given the low income levels, discretionary spending is minimal. Most household income goes to basic necessities. Even small increases in transportation costs or sales tax would significantly impact residents' ability to meet basic needs.
accessibility: High transit dependency with lower car ownership rates compared to city average. Many residents rely on public transit for access to jobs, healthcare, and essential services. Current transit service is limited with longer travel times. Walking and bus are primary modes.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lowest combined costs (fare + tax) given very low incomes. 2. Focus on improved transit service/times since many depend on it. 3. Avoid high driving fees since they would burden essential workers who must drive. 4. Balance between service improvements and affordability. 5. Selected proposals 0, 9, 3, 18, 21 because they maintain low fares/taxes while providing some transit improvements. Lower ranked options had higher costs that would strain household budgets.

disposable_income: Greater Grand Crossing is a lower-income community with median household income around $31,000. Many residents live below poverty level. Disposable income is limited, making residents particularly sensitive to transportation costs.
discretionary_consumption: Limited discretionary spending capacity due to low income levels. Higher sales taxes would significantly impact household budgets. Many residents need to prioritize essential expenses over discretionary purchases.
accessibility: The community has good transit access with multiple bus routes and Red/Green Line stations. Car ownership is lower than city average. Many residents rely on public transit for work commutes and daily needs. Current transit travel times are challenging for residents.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize low transit fares due to limited household incomes and high transit dependency. 2. Favor lower sales tax rates to protect limited discretionary spending. 3. Support moderate driving fees to improve transit service without overly burdening car-dependent trips. 4. Balance travel time improvements with cost impacts. 5. Selected proposals that reduce transit travel times while keeping fares affordable. Ranked proposals with $0.75 fares highest, followed by balanced options with moderate improvements.

disposable_income: Ashburn has a median household income of around $65,000, which is slightly above Chicago's median. However, with significant homeownership rates and family households, residents face substantial fixed expenses
discretionary_consumption: Moderate discretionary spending capacity, with many working-class and middle-class families. Higher sales taxes would impact household budgets, especially for families with children
accessibility: Heavily car-dependent community with limited public transit options. Most residents rely on personal vehicles, though some use Metra SouthWest Service line. Distance from downtown makes commute times significant
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize policies with lower sales tax (0.5-1.0%) due to impact on family budgets. 2. Favor moderate driving fees since most residents drive but need some incentive for transit improvement. 3. Support lower transit fares to encourage occasional transit use. 4. Balance between reducing car travel times and maintaining reasonable costs. 5. Selected policies that don't overly burden drivers while still improving transit service

disposable_income: Auburn Gresham is a predominantly lower-income community with median household income around $35,000, significantly below Chicago's average. Many residents face economic challenges with limited disposable income
discretionary_consumption: Limited discretionary spending capacity due to lower income levels. Residents are price-sensitive to additional taxes and fees. Many households spend a large portion of income on basic necessities
accessibility: High transit dependency with about 30% of households lacking vehicle access. The community is served by CTA Red Line (95th), several bus routes, and Metra Rock Island line. Many residents rely on public transit for work commutes and daily activities
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize low transit fares due to high transit dependency and limited income
2. Favor lower sales tax rates to protect discretionary spending power
3. Support moderate driving fees to improve transit service without excessive burden
4. Balance travel time improvements with cost impacts
5. Selected policies that maintain transit affordability while providing service improvements

disposable_income: Beverly is an upper-middle-class community with median household income around $94,000. Residents have relatively high disposable income compared to Chicago average, making them less sensitive to moderate fare/fee increases
discretionary_consumption: High levels of discretionary spending capacity. Many households can afford cars and have significant retail spending. Higher sales tax would impact discretionary purchases but not severely given income levels
accessibility: Beverly has Metra Rock Island line stations but limited CTA rail access. Many residents are car-dependent for commuting. Good road network with connection to major highways. Mixed transit-car usage with higher car ownership rates
decision_rationale: 1. Given high car ownership and usage, prefer policies with moderate driving fees to reduce congestion while maintaining reasonable car costs. 2. Higher sales tax is acceptable given disposable income levels if it improves transit. 3. Moderate transit fares preferred to maintain service quality while keeping transit competitive. 4. Focus on policies that balance car and transit improvements since residents use both. 5. Selected proposals that reduce travel times for both modes while keeping costs manageable for area's income levels

disposable_income: Washington Heights has a median household income of approximately $41,000, which is below Chicago's median. Many residents face economic constraints, making them sensitive to transportation costs and taxes
discretionary_consumption: Limited discretionary spending capacity due to lower income levels. Residents need to carefully balance essential expenses with transportation costs. Higher sales taxes would significantly impact household budgets
accessibility: The community has access to Metra Rail (95th Street station) and several bus routes, but many residents rely on personal vehicles. Transit travel times are significantly longer than driving. The area is relatively far from downtown employment centers
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower transit fares and sales tax due to limited household incomes. 2. Consider moderate driving fees to improve transit service without overly burdening drivers. 3. Balance between transit improvement and cost burden. 4. Focus on proposals that reduce transit travel time while keeping costs affordable. 5. Selected proposals that maintain reasonable driving costs for car-dependent residents while funding transit improvements

disposable_income: Mount Greenwood is a middle to upper-middle class area with median household income around $87,000. Many residents are police officers, firefighters, and other city workers with stable incomes. The area has one of the highest rates of homeownership in Chicago
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate to high discretionary spending power. Most households own cars and have significant retail spending. Higher sales taxes would impact discretionary spending but not severely given income levels
accessibility: The area is car-dependent with limited public transit access. Located far from downtown, most residents rely on personal vehicles. The Metra Rock Island line serves the area but with limited frequency. Bus service is available but not extensive
decision_rationale:
1. Given car dependency, avoid highest driving fees to not overly burden residents
2. Moderate transit improvements needed but not at highest cost given limited transit usage
3. Can accept moderate sales tax given income levels
4. Balance between driving costs and transit improvements
5. Selected proposals that maintain reasonable car travel times while gradually improving transit

disposable_income: Morgan Park has a median household income of approximately $57,000, which is moderate for Chicago. About 15% of residents live below poverty level, indicating a significant portion of the population needs to be mindful of transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate discretionary spending power. The community has a mix of middle-class and working-class households, with many homeowners but also renters who need to carefully budget transportation expenses
accessibility: Morgan Park is served by Metra Rock Island Line and several bus routes, but is relatively far from L train service. Many residents rely on personal vehicles due to longer transit travel times to reach jobs and services. The area has good road access via I-57 and major arterials
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize policies that balance transit improvement with moderate costs given mixed-income population. 2. Consider driving costs since many residents depend on cars for mobility. 3. Favor lower sales tax rates to preserve discretionary spending power. 4. Look for proposals that reduce transit travel times to improve accessibility. 5. Selected proposals 10, 11, 4, 1, and 13 as they offer good transit time improvements while keeping costs moderate through balanced fee structures

disposable_income: O'Hare has a median household income above city average at around $67,000. Many residents work in airport-related industries or nearby business districts. The community has relatively high disposable income compared to other Chicago areas
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate to high discretionary spending capacity. The area has many retail establishments and restaurants. Higher sales taxes would have a noticeable but manageable impact on consumption
accessibility: The area is highly car-dependent due to its location and layout. While served by the CTA Blue Line, many parts of O'Hare require driving. The community has high car ownership rates and many residents commute by car. Airport workers rely on both transit and driving
decision_rationale:
1. Given high car dependency, avoid highest driving fees to prevent excessive burden on residents
2. Support moderate transit improvements through balanced tax/fare structure
3. Prioritize proposals that reduce driving times without extreme cost increases
4. Consider airport workers who rely on transit by avoiding highest fares
5. Balance between car and transit improvements since community uses both modes
6. Selected proposals 13, 4, 10, 22, 16 as they offer good driving time reductions with moderate fees and reasonable transit improvements

disposable_income: Edgewater has a median household income of around $54,000, slightly below Chicago's median. About 16% of residents live below poverty level. The community has a mix of middle-income professionals and working-class residents, with significant student population due to proximity to Loyola University.
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate discretionary spending capacity. The area has many renters (65%) who need to budget carefully. The presence of diverse retail and dining options along Broadway and Clark Street indicates some disposable income, but residents are price-sensitive.
accessibility: Excellent transit access with Red Line stations (Bryn Mawr, Thorndale, Granville) and multiple bus routes. High walkability score. About 35% of households don't own cars. Many residents commute to downtown and nearby employment centers using public transit.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower transit fares due to high transit dependency and moderate income levels. 2. Support moderate driving fees to improve transit service without overly burdening car-dependent residents. 3. Accept moderate sales tax to maintain transit quality. 4. Balance between travel time improvements and cost burden. 5. Selected proposals that reduce transit travel times while keeping fares affordable. Ranked proposals 11, 10, 19, 13, and 4 as they offer good transit times with reasonable fares and moderate tax impact.
